Crimes.Legal_Issue: Did the PRRA officer correctly apply sections 96 and 97 of IRPA when evaluating new evidence?
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant provided evidence of home break-ins and threats from Delroy Wright after being deported.
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: PRRA application denied due to insufficient evidence of new risks.
Crimes.Court_Ruling: Application for judicial review allowed; case remanded for reconsideration.
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Deported individual seeking protection upon re-entry
Crimes.Defendant_Behavior: Re-entered Canada after deportation without authorization
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Risk of harm in Jamaica due to threats and break-ins
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Sections 96 and 97 of IRPA; requirement to present new evidence under section 113
Crimes.Assessment_Factor: Existence of new risk developments since RPD decision
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Failure to clearly analyze whether evidence constituted new information under section 113
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not explicitly challenged; focus on relevance and timing of evidence
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Reports of home break-ins and threats by Delroy Wright
Crimes.Application_Basis: Pre-Removal Risk Assessment (PRRA) based on alleged new risks
Crimes.Evidence_Assessed: Threats and break-ins presented as new evidence
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Allowance of PRRA application or redetermination
Crimes.Governing_Rule: New evidence must arise after rejection or be previously unavailable
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of clear analysis on whether evidence was 'new' under section 113
Crimes.Outcome: Original decision set aside; referred for redetermination by another officer
Crimes.Harm_Assessment: Risk of retribution from Delroy Wright in Jamaica
Crimes.Cause_Description: Applicant’s PRRA application was denied based on insufficient evidence of new risks
Crimes.Evidence_Handling: PRRA officer dismissed evidence without sufficient justification
Crimes.Evidence_Issues: Unclear evaluation of timeliness and significance of new threats
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Authority of PRRA officer to assess risk upon illegal re-entry
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Insufficient reasoning in rejecting evidence as non-new
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Officer failed to properly apply legal standard for new evidence
Crimes.Evidentiary_Issues: Lack of clarity on treatment of post-rejection evidence
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard applied in judicial review

Crimes.Crime_Name: Using forged or false documents for entry
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the applicant's use of false documents affects pre-removal risk assessment under IRPA sections 96 and 97?
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant re-entered Canada using a false identity after deportation and claimed risk in Jamaica.
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: PRRA application denied due to insufficient evidence of new risks or state protection failure.
Crimes.Court_Ruling: Original PRRA decision invalidated; matter ordered for reconsideration.
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Deported national who re-entered with forged documents
Crimes.Defendant_Behavior: Used false identity to re-enter Canada
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Perceived risk of persecution or harm if returned to Jamaica
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Sections 96 and 97 of IRPA – risk of persecution and state protection
Crimes.Assessment_Factor: Credibility of risk claims despite illegal re-entry
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Fair evaluation of risk despite immigration fraud
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Risk claims not adequately assessed due to procedural shortcomings
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Alleged threats and lack of state protection in Jamaica
Crimes.Application_Basis: PRRA application following illegal re-entry with false documents
Crimes.Evidence_Assessed: Risk of harm in country of origin
Crimes.Governing_Rule: All individuals, regardless of entry method, entitled to risk assessment under IRPA
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to link false documents to credibility or risk assessment
Crimes.Outcome: Decision found unreasonable; referred for redetermination
Crimes.Harm_Assessment: Potential danger upon return to Jamaica
Crimes.Cause_Description: Applicant re-entered Canada illegally and sought protection from removal based on perceived risks in Jamaica
Crimes.Evidence_Handling: Insufficient linkage between document fraud and risk evaluation
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: IRPA provisions related to misrepresentation and admissibility
Crimes.Evidence_Issues: Lack of proper integration of fraudulent entry into risk analysis
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Use of false identity at border
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Scope of PRRA eligibility after illegal re-entry
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Incomplete analysis of how fraud impacts protection claim
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Officer did not reasonably evaluate whether risks were credible despite illegal entry
Crimes.Evidentiary_Issues: Unclear treatment of credibility in light of false documents

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Did the PRRA officer misapply sections 96 and 97 of IRPA in evaluating new evidence?
Crimes.Procedural_Context: Post-refusal risk assessment with new evidence
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Evidence of threats not properly evaluated
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Affidavits regarding home break-ins and threats
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Fear of retribution from Delroy Wright in Jamaica
Crimes.Evaluation_Standard: Whether new evidence meets threshold under section 113
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to assess whether evidence was newly arisen
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Threats and break-ins reported post-RPD decision
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Requirement to consider new evidence arising after refusal
Crimes.Application_Factor: Presence of fresh circumstances in country of origin
Crimes.Decision_Review_Issue: Clarity and justification in evidentiary assessment
Crimes.Governing_Rule_or_Provision: IRPA section 113 – limitation on evidence in PRRA
Crimes.Outcome_of_Review: Remanded for reconsideration by different officer
Crimes.Cause_of_Refusal: Perceived lack of new evidence showing risk in Jamaica
Crimes.Evidentiary_Issues: Unclear analysis of what constitutes 'new' evidence
Crimes.Credibility_Issues: No adverse finding on credibility, but evidence dismissed without explanation
Crimes.Legal_Defense_or_Challenge: Challenge based on unreasonableness and procedural fairness
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Focus: Canada – Federal Court review of immigration decision
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Failure to provide transparent analysis of evidence
Crimes.Omission_Type: Failure to assess newness of evidence
Crimes.Grounds_for_Inadmissibility: Not applicable – issue focused on protection assessment
